attributes.comment:
I object to the fee increases proposed by USCIS called for in document USCIS-
2006-0044. These not only increase the burden to families adopting international,
they are not warranted by the level of poor customer service provided to US
taxpayers.

Despite my fingerprints being on file with the FBI, NSA, and other branches of
government, USCIS would not accept my fingerprints. This required 4 trips over 3
months, each taking 4 hours. In February 2006 on my 3rd trip, the Norfolk office
moved WITH NO NOTICE and was then shut down for 2 weeks. This caused an 8
week delay to submitting my paperwork, which in turn contributed to the now 18
month delay in our adoption.

This 18 month (and growing) delay has prevented me from claiming tax relief and
employer reimbursement, increasing the interest and fees on the $7,000 of loans
I have spent on adoption costs to date.

This increase in costs is yet another smack to adoptive parents who have already
been beaten by an overly burdensome and costly process, an insensitive
bureaucracy, and changing international rules. While I might support increased
fees if paperwork expirations supported growing timeframes and the services
provided by USCIS to US citizens afforded some reasonable quality of customer
service, my experience to date does not merit any increase in fees.

Please address these issues prior to considering any increase that impacts
adoptive parents.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Harvey Summers
